image.altText: A composite image of two photos of the faces of Moira Deeming and John Pesutto.

items.synopsis: Victorian Liberal MPs say they plan to move forward united, after voting to expel first-term upper house MP Moira Deeming from their ranks, a day after she flagged a possible defamation lawsuit against party leader John Pesutto. Follow live.

title.children: Victorian Liberal leader heralds 'turning point' after vote to expel Moira Deeming

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Opposition Leader John Pesutto told gathered reporters that the day represented a "turning point" in a long-term reform process for the Victorian Liberal Party. "I previously asked Victorians to bear with me and my colleagues as we work through that reform process and we are on our way, we are doing solid work and we made real progress today," he said. When quizzed on the 11 MPs which voted against the expulsion motion, he said the overall vote reflected a strong endorsement of a "very challenging" decision. "When any party has to deal with any kind of question of expulsion or suspension is not easy for members, and people can fall on either side of the line," Mr Pesutto said. "But here, as a team, we understood how important it was to make a strong standing, and the party room did that." He reiterated the vote was a matter of unity, rather than individual viewpoints. "What has happened today and in recent weeks has nothing to do with whether somebody is conservative or progressive," he said. "I'm very comfortable with a diversity of viewpoints because I know that the Liberal Party is at its best when that diversity is respected and upheld."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: John Pesutto speaks on the expulsion vote

children.content: Opposition Leader John Pesutto told gathered reporters that the day represented a "turning point" in a long-term reform process for the Victorian Liberal Party.
"I previously asked Victorians to bear with me and my colleagues as we work through that reform process and we are on our way, we are doing solid work and we made real progress today," he said.
When quizzed on the 11 MPs which voted against the expulsion motion, he said the overall vote reflected a strong endorsement of a "very challenging" decision.
"When any party has to deal with any kind of question of expulsion or suspension is not easy for members, and people can fall on either side of the line," Mr Pesutto said.
"But here, as a team, we understood how important it was to make a strong standing, and the party room did that."
He reiterated the vote was a matter of unity, rather than individual viewpoints.
"What has happened today and in recent weeks has nothing to do with whether somebody is conservative or progressive," he said.
"I'm very comfortable with a diversity of viewpoints because I know that the Liberal Party is at its best when that diversity is respected and upheld."
John Pesutto defended his party's decision to expel Moira Deeming
(ABC News)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The meeting has served not only to remove Moira Deeming from the party room, but also to sack Member for Eastern Victoria Region Renee Heath as secretary of the Parliamentary Liberal Party. Ms Heath was sanctioned in the meeting over her taking of party room minutes. She produced three different versions of minutes, one of which was leaked to media. Ms Heath has faced criticism over her links to conservative City builders Church. Former Liberal leader Matthew Guy said Ms Heath would not sit in a party room under him, a decision later overturned by new leader John Pesutto.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Renee Heath out as party room secretary

children.content: The meeting has served not only to remove Moira Deeming from the party room, but also to sack Member for Eastern Victoria Region Renee Heath as secretary of the Parliamentary Liberal Party.
Ms Heath was sanctioned in the meeting over her taking of party room minutes.
She produced three different versions of minutes, one of which was leaked to media.
Ms Heath has faced criticism over
her links to conservative City builders Church.
Former Liberal leader Matthew Guy said Ms Heath would not sit in a party room under him, a decision later overturned by new leader John Pesutto.
Ms Heath was disavowed by then-Liberal Party leader Matthew Guy a week out from the 2022 state election
(Facebook)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Victorian Liberal MPs have voted to expel Moira Deeming from the parliamentary team. Liberal MPs spent over an hour and a half deciding the fate of the Member for Western Metropolitan Region. Ms Deeming will now become an independent MP in the upper house. MP Sam Groth confirmed the news upon leaving the party room. "Yep, Moira's gone," he said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Liberal Party vote to expel Moira Deeming

children.content: Victorian Liberal MPs have voted to expel Moira Deeming from the parliamentary team.
Liberal MPs spent over an hour and a half deciding the fate of the Member for Western Metropolitan Region.
Ms Deeming will now become an independent MP in the upper house.
MP Sam Groth confirmed the news upon leaving the party room.
"Yep, Moira's gone," he said.

image.altText: A woman leaving a meeting room in parliament

items.synopsis: Rebel Victorian MP Moira Deeming has been expelled from the parliamentary Liberal Party after a meeting of MPs this morning, with Renee Heath ditched as partyroom secretary.

title.children: Victorian Liberals eject Moira Deeming from party ranks after bitter stoush with leader

image.altText: A man with a backwards cap holding a football.

items.synopsis: Daniel Hayes was forging a path to a dream career in the AFL 17 years ago — but after leaving the Demons without playing a game, the small forward was left grappling with feelings few understood.

title.children: When Daniel Hayes disappeared from the AFL, he didn't share his pain — now he is suing his junior coach

image.altText: Lara Alexander and John Tucker pose for a photo.

items.synopsis: Concerns over a contentious $715 million stadium and the government's priorities have pushed two Tasmanian MPs to quit the Liberal Party and sit as independents, ending Premier Jeremy Rockliff's majority.

title.children: Anger over Hobart AFL stadium sinks Tasmania's government into minority as MPs quit party

image.altText: People walk through the front door of a house, past a For Lease sign.

items.synopsis: Despite increased rental assistance measures in Tuesday's budget, calls to cap rents are growing louder, with economists saying that step has been successful overseas, however, analysts warn it may make the housing crisis worse.

title.children: 'We need intervention': Renters say price caps are needed to help keep a roof over their heads

image.altText: Justin Tkatchenko with PNG's governor general Sir Bob Bofeng Dadae in formal suits.

items.synopsis: Prime Minister James Marape asks the people of Papua New Guinea to "forgive" the country's foreign minister after his apology for his "primitive animals" comments.

title.children: 'Unsavoury use of words': PNG's PM says he was offended by foreign minister's 'primitive animals' comment

image.altText: A man in a business shirt and tie looks seriously off the camera.

items.synopsis: The report contains highly critical reviews of NT Police processes and concerns raised by prosecutors about the expert witnesses called in the murder case against former police officer Zachary Rolfe.

image.altText: Peter Dutton Budget reply

items.synopsis: Opposition Leader Peter Dutton says JobSeeker recipients should be allowed to work more hours without it eating into their payments, as he responds to the federal budget.

title.children: Dutton says JobSeeker recipients should be allowed to work more instead of having payments increased

image.altText: Jeremy Rockliff appears to be in thought, surrounded by his colleagues.

items.synopsis: Just yesterday, the Tasmanian government was sailing along relatively smoothly as the only remaining Liberal government in the country, but two bombshell resignations have changed all that, writes Adam Langenberg.

title.children: The Tasmanian premier's $715 million stadium is costing him more than money

image.altText: A serious-looking woman standing on the bank of a creek behind her and staring up into the sun.

items.synopsis: Larrakia traditional owners raised concerns with federal and territory ministers about the potential impact of a major industrial hub planned for Darwin before $1.5 billion of Commonwealth funding was confirmed.

title.children: 'They need to be protected at all costs': Traditional owners fear for cultural sites at $1.5 billion industrial hub

image.altText: Former president Donald Trump claps his hand together at rally in Manchester, New Hampshire.

items.synopsis: Donald Trump signals he will appeal against a jury's decision to find him liable for sexual abuse and defamation, a day after joking about the case during a controversial CNN broadcast.

title.children: Trump lodges appeal against sexual abuse finding as CNN grapples with town hall fallout

image.altText: Dutton wearing glasses speaks on the floor of parliament house.

items.synopsis: Peter Dutton failed to sketch a big picture to look like an alternative prime minister in his Thursday night budget reply, writes Michelle Grattan.

title.children: Peter Dutton's concern for the 'working poor' not enough to demonstrate big-picture vision in budget reply

image.altText: A close up photo of Sophie, Duchess of Edinburgh under an umbrella. She is smiling.

items.synopsis: A woman in her 80s remains in critical condition after being hit by a police motorcycle that was escorting Sophie, Duchess of Edinburgh.

title.children: Police investigation launched after Duchess of Edinburgh's motorcycle escort hits elderly woman

image.altText: Profile shot of Ms R Rubuntja

items.synopsis: The Albanese government allocated $194 million to prevent domestic violence against First Nations women in Tuesday's budget. With some of the highest rates of domestic violence in the world, is it enough?

title.children: 'Three friends of mine have been killed by their partners': Are we on track to end violence against women?

image.altText: Voyager

items.synopsis: Australia will compete in the 2023 Eurovision grand final, with synth-metal band Voyager voted in after a glittering performance in the second semifinal.

title.children: Australia's Voyager is through to the Eurovision 2023 grand final

image.altText: Craig Kelly in a yellow hat.

items.synopsis: United Australia Party national director Craig Kelly says the TGA 'surrendered" on antiparasitic drug ivermectin with its decision to allow off-label prescription once again. But what actually happened?

title.children: Former Liberal MP Craig Kelly claims the TGA has 'surrendered' on ivermectin. Is that correct?

image.altText: Jacob van Rooyen hits Charlie Ballard across the head as Ballard attempts to mark the ball

items.synopsis: Following a marathon hearing at the AFL appeals board, Jacob van Rooyen's two-match suspension is overturned, allowing the 20-year-old to play for the Demons against the Hawks this weekend.

title.children: Young Demon van Rooyen free to play after successful appeal

image.altText: Man wearing white Islamic cap with long brown beard sits in study with books behind and window with laced curtains behind

items.synopsis: A convicted terrorist is being kept in prison using orders that have been condemned in a Home Affairs inquiry. The department kept that report's findings secret — until now.

title.children: Home Affairs releases secret report trashing orders keeping terrorist behind bars

image.altText: Irina Tsybaneva stands in a courtroom in St. Petersburg, Russia.

items.synopsis: A Russian court gives a two-year suspended sentence to a St Petersburg woman who left a note on the grave of President Vladimir Putin's parents on the eve of his birthday that said they had "raised a freak and a killer".

title.children: 'You raised a freak and a killer': 60yo who left note on Putin's parents' grave convicted

image.altText: The ASX close to steady in early trade as seen on the exchange's board at its Sydney office

items.synopsis: Falls across most of the resources sector and a big drop for QBE on its latest earnings update are weighing the ASX down in morning trade. Stay across the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX weighed down by QBE earnings update, mining sell-off

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As we approach the mid-point of the trading day, the ASX is still posting very moderate losses. The benchmark ASX 200 index was down 0.2% at 7,240 points at 12:33pm AEST, while the broader All Ords was also off 0.2% at 7,436. As in early trade, it is the resources sector letting down the market, with both miners and energy companies losing ground. Basic materials (mostly mining) was down 1.4% and energy was off 1.2%. Every other sector was up, but this is Australia, and half of our corporate profits come from resource extraction, so where the miners go, often the market goes. Education and healthcare were still the biggest gainers. The best performers around 12:35pm were: Lake Resources: +8.7% to $0.625 Graincorp: +5.3% to $8.225 BrainChip Holdings: +4.6% to $0.46 News Corp: +4.5% to $25.92 Nanosonics: +2.8% to $5.55 The worst performers were: Sandfire Resources: -6% to $6.11 Regis Resources: -5.4% to $2.035 Evolution Mining: -5% to $3.685 West African Resources: -4.1% to $0.935 De Grey Mining: -3.9% to $1.4325
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX remains slightly in the red by the middle of the trading session

children.content: As we approach the mid-point of the trading day, the ASX is still posting very moderate losses.
The benchmark ASX 200 index was down 0.2% at 7,240 points at 12:33pm AEST, while the broader All Ords was also off 0.2% at 7,436.
As in early trade, it is the resources sector letting down the market, with both miners and energy companies losing ground.
Basic materials (mostly mining) was down 1.4% and energy was off 1.2%.
Every other sector was up, but this is Australia, and half of our corporate profits come from resource extraction, so where the miners go, often the market goes.
Education and healthcare were still the biggest gainers.
The best performers around 12:35pm were:
Lake Resources: +8.7% to $0.625
Graincorp: +5.3% to $8.225
BrainChip Holdings: +4.6% to $0.46
News Corp: +4.5% to $25.92
Nanosonics: +2.8% to $5.55
The worst performers were:
Sandfire Resources: -6% to $6.11
Regis Resources: -5.4% to $2.035
Evolution Mining: -5% to $3.685
West African Resources: -4.1% to $0.935
De Grey Mining: -3.9% to $1.4325

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: This short statement out today from Medibank: "Late on 11 May 2023, the Office of the Australian Information Commissioner (OAIC) advised Medibank that it has decided to proceed with the investigation of the representative complaint lodged by Maurice Blackburn on 18 November 2022. "The OAIC advised it will proceed with the investigation of the representative complaint at the same time as the Commissioner's own investigation. "Medibank continues to support its customers from the impact of the cybercrime through our previously announced Cyber Response Support Program which includes mental health and wellbeing support, identity protection and financial hardship measures." This is some further context of the legal actions underway against Medibank over the data breach, with Slater and Gordon last week also announcing a class action .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Medibank facing privacy breach investigation as customers seek compensation

featuredLink.title: Class action firms join forces to litigate Medibank breach

children.content: This short statement out today from Medibank:

"Late on 11 May 2023, the Office of the Australian Information Commissioner (OAIC) advised Medibank that it has decided to proceed with the investigation of the representative complaint lodged by Maurice Blackburn on 18 November 2022.
"The OAIC advised it will proceed with the investigation of the representative complaint at the same time as the Commissioner's own investigation.

"Medibank continues to support its customers from the impact of the cybercrime through our previously announced Cyber Response Support Program which includes mental health and wellbeing support, identity protection and financial hardship measures."
This is some further context of the legal actions underway against Medibank over the data breach, with
Slater and Gordon last week also announcing a class action

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As indicated by the futures market, it's a pretty flat start to trade on the ASX. The ASX 200 was up 1 point at 7,253 around 10:15am AEST — that's point, not per cent — and the All Ords was down 2 points at 7,448. Most companies in the top 200 were doing well, with 131 in the black and only 65 in the red. But the mining sector, notably the big iron ore miners, were among those losing ground, weighing on the index as a whole. BHP (-1.7%), Rio Tinto (-1.4%) and Fortescue (-1.6%) were all down after spot iron ore prices dropped below $US100 a tonne, continuing recent trends on signs of Chinese economic weakness. QBE was another big company dragging on the market — investors clearly not impressed with its first quarter performance update, despite 11% growth in gross written premium. The company did warn about the cost of a number of natural disasters, which is already creeping towards its first half catastrophe allowance with a couple of months yet to go. QBE shares were down 5.1 per cent to $14.39. Healthcare, education and consumer cyclicals were today's leading sectors, with energy joining mining as the laggards. The big four banks were up between 0.2 and 1 per cent, with Westpac leading. Five biggest gains on ASX 200: News Corp: +4.1% to $25.81 GrainCorp: +2.6% to $8.015 Sayona Mining: +2.4% to $0.215 Imugene: +2.1% to $0.1225 Polynovo: +1.6% to $1.4125 Five biggest losses on ASX 200: Sandfire Resources: -5.2% to $6.16 QBE Insurance: -4.8% to $14.43 Champion Iron: -3.7% to $6.20 Regis Resources: -3.7% to $2.07 Paladin Energy: -3.7% to $0.66
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Miners, QBE weigh on ASX in early trade

image.altText: Lesley Trotter in khaki hiking gear sitting on a rock with other walkers.

items.synopsis: Police believe the 78-year-old was killed the day she was reported missing — her body put in a wheelie bin near her home in Toowong, which was then collected by a rubbish truck.

title.children: Dumped in a bin outside her house six weeks ago, Lesley Trotter's disappearance remains a mystery

image.altText: Crash investigators inspect an off-road vehicle that has been loaded onto a truck.

items.synopsis: The national motorsport peak body has told a court it failed to do enough to keep people safe in the years leading up to a spectator's death at the Finke Desert Race in 2021.

title.children: Scathing safety report not acted on by organisers prior to fatal Finke Desert Race, inquest hears

image.altText: A handsome young man poses in a black and white photo with his hand on his chin

title.children: The young Harvard grad, the heiress and the coup leader: Inside Thailand's crucial race for PM

image.altText: Twitter logo and a photo of Elon Musk are displayed through magnifier in an illustration.

items.synopsis: Pakistan's Supreme Court orders the release of former prime minister Imran Khan, after his arrest sparked countrywide violence.
